required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: A Comparison of Ambu® AuraGain™ Laryngeal Mask Airway and I-gel in Adult
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized Comparison of Ambu® AuraGain™ Laryngeal Mask Airway and I-gel in Patients With Simulated Cervical Immobilization

brief_summary.textblock:
The supraglottic airway device(SAD), as an alternative to the endotracheal tube is inserted into the oral cavity and seals the upper esophagus and the surrounding tissue, effectively securing airway. SAD has evolved in recent years to increase efficiency and secure safety. The recently developed Ambu® AuraGain™ is a second-generation SAD with a built-in gastric port and is designed to be fitted well in the larynx and oral cavity after insertion because the shaft is bent at an angle of 90 degrees and has an inflatable cuff.
In a previous study, Ambu® AuraGain™ showed a higher sealing pressure and better fibreoptic finding compared to LMA Supreme in laparoscopic surgery.
On the other hand, I-gel and Ambu® AuraGain™, both of the second-generation SAD, show comparatively excellent performance according to the results of previous studies. However, there are no studies comparing the characteristics of two airway devices in adults.
The purpose of this study is to compare the performance of I-gel and Ambu® AuraGain™ to make a difficult airway-like situation using cervical collar for adult patients receiving mechanical ventilation under general anesthesia.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At an average of 30 seconds after insertion of laryngeal mask airway
primary_outcome.description: Oropharyngeal leak pressure is measured by closing the expiratory valve and administering fresh gas flow of 6 L/min, until the equilibrium pressure is reached (to a maximum of 40 cm of H2O).

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 5 minute after insertion of laryngeal mask airway
secondary_outcome.description: Oropharyngeal leak pressure is measured by closing the expiratory valve and administering fresh gas flow of 6 L/min, until the equilibrium pressure is reached (to a maximum of 40 cm of H2O).

secondary_outcome.measure: The time for successful insertion of the device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: The total time is measured from the removal of the face mask until bilateral chest rise with the first capnogram upstroke.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: Successful insertion of laryngeal mask airway in a first attempt

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: Successful insertion of laryngeal mask airway in a maximum of three attempts

secondary_outcome.measure: The ease of insertion of device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: The ease of placement was assessed using a subjective scale of 1-4 (1= no resistance, 2 = moderate resistance, 3 = high resistance, 4 = inability to place the device)

secondary_outcome.measure: The number of attempts at insertion of device
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 60 seconds
secondary_outcome.description: The number of attempts for successful insertion of laryngeal mask airway

secondary_outcome.measure: The ease of gastric tube placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The ease of gastric tube placement was graded on a subjective scale (1 = easy, 2 = difficult, 3 = unable to pass)

secondary_outcome.measure: The time for successful gastric tube placement
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The insertion time is measured from first handling of the gastric tube to confirmation of its position in the stomach by aspiration of gastric fluid.

secondary_outcome.measure: The grade of fiberoptic bronchoscopic view
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During induction of anesthesia, an average of 5 minutes
secondary_outcome.description: The fiberoptic bronchoscopic view is defined as Grade 1, larynx only seen; Grade 2, larynx and epiglottis posterior surface seen; Grade 3, larynx, and epiglottis tip or anterior surface seen—visual obstruction of epiglottis to larynx: < 50%; Grade 4, epiglottis down-folded, and its anterior surface seen—visual obstruction of epiglottis to larynx: > 50%; Grade 5, epiglottis downfolded and larynx cannot be seen directly.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: At 5 minute after insertion of laryngeal mask airway
secondary_outcome.description: Peak inspiratory pressure is recorded from mechanical ventilator.

secondary_outcome.measure: The number of airway maneuvers required to maintain airway patency
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the surgery, an average of 2 hours after anesthesia induction
secondary_outcome.description: Airway maneuvers required to maintain airway patency, including jaw thrust, head/neck extension and/or device adjustments such as advancement/withdrawal of device, and alterations to cuff volume.

secondary_outcome.measure: The type of airway maneuvers required to maintain airway patency
secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the surgery, an average of 2 hours after anesthesia induction
secondary_outcome.description: Airway maneuvers required to maintain airway patency, including jaw thrust, head/neck extension and/or device adjustments such as advancement/withdrawal of device, and alterations to cuff volume.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: During the surgery, an average of 2 hours after anesthesia induction
secondary_outcome.description: Intraoperative complications including coughing, laryngospasm, bronchospasm, hypoxia (SpO2 < 90%), regurgitation, aspiration, blood staining of the device.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: An average of 2 hours after extubation
secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative complications including sore throat, hoarseness/dysphonia, jaw, neck or ear pain, persistent cough, tachypnea, stridor, hypoxia (SpO2 < 90%), nausea and vomiting.

intervention.description: After induction of anesthesia, Ambu® AuraGain™ will be inserted for the mechanical ventilation.
After induction of anesthesia, I-gel will be inserted for the mechanical ventilation.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Patients who are undergoing surgery under general anesthesia where supraglottic airway management will be appropriate.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Body mass index > 35 kg/m2
- High risk of regurgitation (hiatus hernia, gastro-esophageal reflux disease, non-fasting status)
- Criteria for difficult airway
- Patients with cervical disease or previous cervical spine surgery
